fields.answer:
A recent version of Docker is available as part of the HeliumOS installation. However, there are a couple of steps needed to use Docker. For rootful Docker: Enable the Docker Daemon using the terminal
``` sudo systemctl enable --now docker.service ``` Now you can use rootful Docker with `sudo docker ps` or similar commands. If you want to use rootful Docker without sudo, see the official [Docker Engine documentation](https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/linux-postinstall/) for more details. For rootless Docker: Run the rootless Docker helper script
``` dockerd-rootless-setuptool.sh install ``` Docker containers managed using commands such as `docker ps` will now be rootless.

fields.task: How to check if my CPU is x86_64-v3 compatible?
fields.answer:
On an existing Linux system, run the following command:

```bash
/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 --help | grep 'x86-64-v3 (supported, searched)'
```

If that command returns output of `x86-64-v3 (supported, searched)`, then your system is x86_64-v3 compatible. If the output of the command is blank, then your device is unfortunately incompatible with x86_64-v3 and HeliumOS 10.
